titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Friday. Letter to Louis M’Lane, Secretary of the Treasury, about the claim of the heirs of Casaux, and the Agents Stuart and Grubb— At the House— Duncan of Illinois presented Resolutions of the Legislature of that State, approving the Sentiments expressed by the President relating to the disposal of the Public Lands—and asking for a reduction of their price, to carry his views into effect— That is to give the Lands away— Wilde’s motion for re-consideration was taken up— Wilde himself absent.— I finished my Speech— Alexander of Virginia, a member of the Committee of Ways and Means—Wayne—Clayton of Georgia— Wickliffe proposes that by unanimous consent, Wilde’s motion should be laid on the table— I said that although I had been desirous that the question should be taken by yeas and nays, I would in the Spirit of conciliation consent to lay it on the table— But John Davis objected, and the hour elapsed. The Tariff-bill resumed in Committee of the whole. Campbell P. White’s proposed Amendments discussed—Horace Everett’s—Root’s—Beardsley’s—D. J Pearce’s— Votes by Tellers vibrating for and against the bill— The Committee rose at 5. P.M— Adjourned—upon which the yeas and nays were called for and refused. I walked home— John’s child Mary-Louisa, taken exceedingly ill, late this Evening. Dr Huntt was sent for, and came.
2. V. Saturday.

Nearly sleepless Night— Mrs Tudor sent in to ask to see me last Evening, and I called on her this morning— She was very anxious for the passage of a Bill upon her Petition, and gave me a printed pamphlet, on the claims of Mrs Eastin and Mrs Storer, daughters of Coll. R B. Harrison, which I gave to Mr Muhlenberg chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Claims.— At the House. Mr Wilde’s motion for reconsideration, after Speeches by John Davis, Wayne and Clayton, was withdrawn by him. Previous question carried upon a motion for reconsideration by Plummer of Mississippi, and the reconsideration refused—concerning the demand of increased Appropriations for the Land-Office— The Tariff Bill again in Committee of the whole. Campbell P. White’s amendments debated— Speeches of John Davis, Bouldin, Cambreleng, and Stewart of Pennsylvania—debate continued till 5. P.M. Committee then rose— Several Bills from the Senate committed— Joint Resolution passed, and Committee appointed to ascertain and report a mode of examining the votes of President and Vice-President of the United States, and of notifying the persons elected of their election. 5 Members appointed on the part of the House. Adjourned after 5. Walk home— Talk with T. R. Mitchell, who votes for the Bill, but is against it— Evening visit from Joshua Evans of Pennsylvania, with a Mr Jacobs of the same State.
3. V:30. Sunday.

Heard at the Capitol Bishop Emory of the Protestant Episcopal Church. from Isaiah 60.22. “A little one shall become a thousand, and a small one a strong Nation— I the Lord will hasten it in his time”—upon prophesy—there is something remarkable in this text, in the grammatical transition from the first to the third person in the name of the Lord— Mr Hammett, the Chaplain of the House introduced the preacher to me, and also Mr Bond— Walk home; partly with Mr Knight, the Senator from Rhode Island— Heard in the afternoon at St. John’s church; who read the Evening Service for the fourth Sunday after the Epiphany; and gave an exposition of Nebuchadnezzars dream. from Daniel 2.45 the latter part of the verse—“The great God hath made known to the king what shall come to pass hereafter: and the dream is certain and the interpretation thereof sure.”— Evening visit from Chief Justice Marshall, and Judge Story— I have not yet recovered from the idleness of disease—
4. VI:30. Monday.

Walk to the House. I presented a petition from the Citizens of Plymouth for a mail route to Middleborough—referred to the Committee on Post-Offices and Post-roads— Appleton presented the Boston Petition against the Tariff Bill—debate on printing—carried by yeas and nays 88 to 95— Heister presented a petition for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia. Debate on reference to the Committee on the District— Mason of Virginia objects—Jenifer— Motion to lay on the Table. I asked for the yeas and nays—70 to 95— Mason withdrew his motion, and apologised to me— Milligan presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Delaware, against South-Carolina Nullification and approving the President’s Proclamation, and pledging to its support the People of the State— Wayne presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Georgia, against appropriations by Congress, to subscribe for Stock in State Corporations, and declaring that the Government of the United States does not possess the power to carry on a system of internal improvement within the States: nor of appropriating money to be expended on such improvements— Wilde presents other Resolutions of the Legislature of Georgia, making application to Congress in conformity with the fifth Article of the federal Constitution, for the call of a Convention of the People, for its amendment in thirteen enumerated particulars, and any others desired by the People of the other States. The Tariff-Bill further discussed in Committee of the whole. Ward of New-York speaks in favour of the Bill. Wardwell and Leavitt against it— I moved to strike out the enacting clause, and made a Speech—Barringer—Burges—Drayton of South-Carolina grossly misrepresents me—my answer—he replies and persists— Misrepresents the Legislature of Massachusetts. Patton of Virginia has the floor. Committee rise— Adjourn at 6. Mr Connell and Mr Eyre of Philadelphia were here this Evening— Both John’s children very ill— Dr Huntt here late at Night.
5. V:15. Tuesday.

Resolution of the House to meet in future at 11. O’Clock. A.M. passed at the motion of Elisha Whittlesey, by yeas and nays 115 to 28. Edward Everett presents a Memorial from Middlesex County, Massachusetts in favour of domestic industry— Appleton’s call, on the Secretary of the Treasury, passed the House without a division— Tariff-Bill in Committee of the whole— Patton’s Speech of three hours against me and my Speech— John W. Taylor makes a question of order, upon my motion— The Chairman decides the motion is in order—
My motion to strike out the enacting clause, rejected, 68 to 86. Campell P. White’s Amendments, amended, adopted and rejected— Clause for laying additional duties on Silks struck out. Long debate on discrimination between European and India silks— Adjourned about 6. P.M. On coming home I found Lieutt. T. B. Adams, arrived from Augusta Georgia— Evening visit from Elisha R. Potter junr of Rhode-Island with a Letter of Introduction from Dutee J. Pearce.
6. VI:15. Wednesday

Mr Stokes was here again this morning. I told him that Mr W. B Shepherd had received an answer to the enquiries concerning Stokes’s uncle’s Will— There was a copy of the Will in the probate Office; but one of the Executors was drowned, and the other now at Dumfries in Scotland. I proposed to him to procure a copy of the Will, to which he assented— The House met at 11. A.M. Speight from the joint Committee reported a Resolution, for opening and counting the votes for President and Vice-President of the United States this day week— It was adopted, and two Tellers on the part of the House, Drayton and Hubbard were appointed— Sundry other Resolutions were discussed— Tariff-Bill in Committee of the whole— Numerous amendments offered—some adopted—others rejected— Coke of Virginia moves to rise and report the Bill— Russell of Ohio moves to strike out all but the enacting clause, and to limit the act of 14. July last to 3. March 1841— The Committee rose and the House adjourned at 6. P.M. I took out from the Library the Debates of the Virginia Convention, on the Constitution of the United States, and Ramsay’s Life of Washington— I met Mr Benjamin Gorham of Boston, at the House, and invited him to dine with me on Saturday.
7. IV:30. Thursday

At the House. Resolutions called for.— N. Appleton; gone home upon leave of absence for the remainder of the Session— Milligan presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Delaware, against a Convention of the States to amend the Constitution of the United States proposed by the Legislature of South-Carolina, and disclaiming as unconstitutional any Convention of the States— A Message was received from the President, with a report from the Secretary of State on the subject of our diplomatic intercourse with foreign Nations. Bills from the Senate— Act for explaining the 18th. Section of the Tariff-Act of 14. July 1832. Cambreleng lukewarm—moves to suspend the rule, to continue the discussion upon it beyond the hour—refused—92 ayes. Speaker Stevenson miscounts 56 for 38 I remonstrated in vain.— Tariff-Bill in Committee of the whole— Russell of Ohio withdraws his motion— Several amendments proposed. Ellsworth offers to capitulate— Speight almost accepts the offer. C. C. Clay moves the Committee to rise and report the Bill. I replied to Drayton and Patton.— They both rejoined— Committee rose and reported the Bill with amendments to be printed— House adjourned about four.— Weather cold— My wife, my Son John, and both his children again very unwell— Myself much indisposed— Evening idly wasted.
8. V.15. Friday

Mr Bigelow came to ask me to return the Report of the Committee of the Senate upon the Casaux claim in 1826, which I gave him— Lieutt. T. B. Adams went with me to the Capitol. It was a quarter past 11. and there had been a call of the House, so that we were for sometime excluded— The annual Report from the Commissioners of the sinking fund was received— About noon I went into the Senate chamber, and heard a debate between Webster, Tyler and Brown of North Carolina— Dallas began a Speech— I was called back to the House— Tariff-Bill in discussion— Motion to postpone the Bill till Monday rejected.
Amendments to the clause on Wool and Woollens debated—Root—Beardsley. J. Davis. Stewart—Craig and others— Yeas and Nays three times taken—votes varying. Beardsley told me no Bill could possibly pass at this Session— Adjourned at half past four. Walk with J. W. Taylor John’s child Fanny dangerously ill with the scarlet fever
9. VI. Saturday.

John’s child Fanny has the scarlet fever very severely— Lieutt. T. B. Adams and Julia deWint went with me to the Capitol. At the House. No Quorum at 11. Call of the House moved for, but refused by yeas and nays 39 to 46. The Speaker laid before the House two Letters from the Secretary of the Treasury, with Statements of the amount of duties collected under the several Tariff Acts from 1816 to 1832. and estimating at 18 Millions the amount to be produced by the Bill before the house. The second Letter is in answer to N. Appleton’s Call—but Appleton is gone. Bouldin moved that 25000 copies of the Report of the Judiciary committee, made yesterday by its Chairman, Bell of Tennessee, upon the President’s Proclamation Message, should be printed— The Bill provides for the enforcement of the revenues Laws; but the report does not sustain the Doctrines of the Proclamation, and is largely tainted with Nullification absurdities— The Navy Appropriation Bill was taken up, passed through the Committee of the whole, and the House to be engrossed for a third reading. Wickliffe proposed an amendment to limit the number of Midshipmen to be appointed—much debated—finally rejected by yeas and nays 102 to 88— Adjourned soon after 3. Walk home. Spring-like weather— We had company to dine— My wife’s cough is racking and ceaseless— Dr Huntt was called out from the dinner Table to the child, who is fearfully ill.
10. V. Sunday.

John’s child Fanny had a very bad night— Dr Huntt was sent for, and found her condition alarming— My own feelings are inexpressible— Heard this Morning Mr Smith from Acts 17:26. “And hath made of one blood all Nations of Men”— It was a Discourse for the Orphan Asylum, the children of which were all there— A Collection was taken, for the support of the Institution; which has lost its chief Patroness, Mrs Van Ness, wife to the Mayor of the City— He was present. Morning visits from Mr Hassler and Mr Fendall— Heard afternoon, Mr Hawley at St. John’s Church, from Leviticus 25.11. “A jubile shall that fiftieth year be unto you.” He read the Evening service for the fifth Sunday after the Epiphany. Mrs W. S. Smith was here. We flatter ourselves this Evening that the child is a little better—

11. V. Monday.— The child is yet very distressingly ill, and my wife’s cough has but partially abated— I reached the House a few minutes before 11. No Quorum at 11. Call of the House moved for, but refused— Motion for a recess made and rejected— Thursday next was fixed, at the motion of Hubbard of New-Hampshire for the election of a Printer to the House for the next Congress. Bouldin’s motion to print 25000 copies of the report of the judiciary Committee on the President’s proclamation gave rise to a very warm debate— No decision— The Navy Appropriation Bill, and some others passed— That for refunding Matthew Lyon’s fine to his legal Representatives passed to be engrossed— I went into the Senate chamber, and heard a Speech from Miller of South-Carolina—returned to the House— Tariff-Bill— One question of amendment taken and carried. Wickliffe gave notice that he would to-morrow move to lay the Bill on the Table. Dearborn made the same motion this day—rejected 113 to 85— Drayton moved to recommit the Bill, with Instructions to report a short Bill—other motions followed, by Irvin of Ohio, Wickliffe,
and Wardwell— Wayne moved to postpone the Bill till to-morrow, which was carried. Adjourned at half past 3. Walk home. Mr Clay gave notice in the Senate, that he would to-morrow ask leave to introduce a Bill upon this subject— Clay and Calhoun are said to have settled the question between themselves.

12. V. Tuesday.— At the House, Edward Everett presented the Memorial of the New-York institute, in support of the protection due to the manufacturing industry of the Country. Bouldin’s Resolution for printing 25000 copies of the Report of the Judiciary Committee, was again debated between Foster of Georgia and Stewart of Pennsylvania; and after the number was reduced to 10,000 copies, and Whittlesey of Ohio, moved for the previous Question— It was sustained and the Resolution was carried— The Bill to explain the 18th. Section of the Tariff-Act of 14 July 1832 was superseded. White of Florida’s Bill of Indemnity for East-Florida sufferers was postponed, and recommitted— Wickliffe without due authority appealed to me for testimony— Tariff Bill resumed. Drayton modified his motion, to recommit the Bill, with Instructions to the Committee to report another— He now produced the specific Bill, which he moved that the Committee should be instructed to report. He made a short and feeble Speech in support of it; and it was debated by Wickliffe, Irwin of Ohio, Cambreleng, Bouldin, Wayne, Arnold and Bell of Tennessee, John Davis and Huntington—Isaacs, Clay of Alabama, Carson, Hubbard and Wilde. Adjourned after 4— H. Clay obtained leave to introduce his Tariff-bill into the Senate— Concerted with John C. Calhoun— Ellsworth in the House is for a compromise. John Davis against it. Walk homewards with Richard M Johnson who is greatly incensed at the new Coalition, between Clay and Calhoun.— My wife’s cough is unabated. The child’s fever is less acute that it has been for the last three days.

13. V. Wednesday.— At the House— The Speaker laid before the house a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, with returns of Statements respecting the condition of the State Banks— Polk from the Committee of Ways and Means reported a Bill for the sale at the market value, not under par of the seven Millions of United States Bank Stock belonging to the Government. Wickliffe moved its rejection at the first reading, and sustained his motion by a Speech— Answered by Polk. Ingersoll and Watmough replied. Previous question moved by Whittlesey and carried 94 to 90—and the bill rejected by yeas and nays 102 to 98— Verplanck disconcerted. Said the Bank was ruining itself— Quos Deus vult perdere, prius dementat.— At one O’Clock, the Senate came in— Hugh Lawson White President pro Tempore of the Senate, presided. The Electoral votes for President and Vice-President of the United States, were opened, counted, and announced— Of 288 votes, Andrew Jackson had 219. for President— Henry Clay 49. John Floyd 11. William Wirt 7. For Vice-President, Martin Van Buren 189. John Sergeant 49. William Wilkins 30 Amos Ellmaker 7. Wirt and Ellmaker were the Anti-masonic vote of Vermont— Floyd and Lee the nullification, Anti-Tariff vote of South Carolina. Clay and Sergeant the Masonic National Republican vote—and the 30. Jackson votes of Pennsylvania, were given for Wilkins as Vice-President, instead of Van-Buren. Andrew Jackson was then proclaimed to be elected as President, and Martin Van-Buren as Vice President of the United States for four years from the 4th. of March next; the Senate withdrew, and the House shortly after 3. O’Clock adjourned— I had some conversation with John Davis, who disapproves the compromise between Clay and Calhoun; and said Clay had step’d over the Potowmack.

14. V. Thursday.— At the House— John Anderson of Maine moved that the Committee on military Affairs be instructed to inquire into the expediency of authorising the President of the United States to employ a suitable person, in aid of the topographical bureau for the purpose of ascertaining the Geology and Mineralogy of each of the several States of the Union, with the view to the construction of a mineralogical and geological map of the whole territory of the United States— This motion gave rise to much debate.— Vinton moved to strike out the words, under the act of 1824—which was carried. Hall of North-Carolina moved to lay the Resolution on the table which was rejected— Arnold of Tennessee moved to refer the enquiry to the Committee on Roads and Canals—negatived—and the Resolution finally passed— From Noon till half past 4 was consumed in balloting for a Printer to the House of Representatives for the next Congress, without effecting a choice.— Francis P. Blair, publisher of the Globe Newspaper, had from 89 to 98 votes—the administration strength in the house— Gales and Seaton from 60 to 84— Duff Green 25. Condy Raguet 10— Thurlow Weed 12. and always several blanks— Judge Wayne made a question whether the blanks should be counted— They were counted— I walked home Evening unwell— My wife keeps her bed. John’s child we hope is better.
15. IV:30 Friday.

Snow, all day. At the House, Speight from the joint Committee reported that a Committee of two members on the part of the House, to join a committee of the Senate to wait upon Andrew Jackson of Tennessee and notify him of his election as President of the United States for four years from the 4th. of March next; and also to notify Martin Van Buren of New-York of his election as Vice-President of the United States for the same term—which Resolution was read and adopted by the House— Several private Bills were carried through the Committee of the whole, Crawford of Pennsylvania in the chair— At noon the balloting for Printer to the House of Representatives for the next Congress recommenced— At the first ballot there werevotes for Blair, andfor Gales and Seaton— There were still votes for Condy Raguet, and Duff Green, and Blanks At the third Ballot Gales and Seaton hadand BlairThen commenced the dilatory movements— Hall of North Carolina moved to postpone the election till the next Session of Congress, which was contrary to Law— He finally withdrew the motion— Boon of Indiana moved to postpone till the 3d. of March which will be on a sunday. then to the second and called the yeas and nays— Lewis Williams moved to lay Boon’s motion on the table, which the Speaker said was not in order— Wickliffe doubted but did not appeal. Boon’s motion was rejected by yeas and nays 92 to 101— At the next, 4th. Ballot, the votes were 197—Gales and Seaton had 99: and were chosen— A buzz of Satisfaction went round the Hall outside of the Bar— I secured this election to Gales and Seaton, by prevailing upon the Anti-masons 12 of whom had at the first ballot voted for Thurlow Weed, to vote finally for them— Three or four of them yielded with great reluctance— The House adjourned at half-past 2— I went into the Library, and then to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and read a Canto of Rose’s Translation of Ariosto—waiting for my Carriage— Rode home— My wife keeps her bed with an incessant racking cough, and frequent fever— John’s child Fanny is better.
16. V:15. Saturday

Dr. Huntt bled Mrs Adams this morning— In the House, several Appropriation Bills were passed in Committee of the whole, and reported to the House. Two or three private Bills occupied half an hour. There was a Call of the House, and three or four motions, successively to adjourn— No signs of the Tariff-bill— Drayton not in the House— Absent by reason of sickness— About two O’Clock the House adjourned. It was impossible
to keep a Quorum in the House. I went to the Senate-chamber, which was so crowded that it was a full quarter of an hour before I could get in— Mr Webster was speaking in answer to Mr Calhoun, upon what is called the enforcing bill— His argument was to prove, that the Government of the United States was a Government of the People, and not a compact between States. It is both—and all Constitutional Government is a compact. He spoke till 3. when the Senate took a recess till 5— Mr Webster is a very handsome Speaker—but he overlaboured a point as plain as day; and he hung his cause upon a broken hinge, in maintaining that a Government was not a compact— I met my Carriage and rode home. Lieutt. T. B. Adams has orders to go to Baltimore, and there take 50 recruits on by water to New-York— After which he has leave of absence to go home till the 10th. of April, when he is to go upon Ordnance duty to Pittsburgh— Mr Manuel Eyre was here this Evening—going for Philadelphia to-morrow.
17. VI. Sunday.

My wife’s cough is extremely distressing, and almost incessant Night and day. Yet I slept several hours last Night, and she had also some respite of Sleep. Lieutenant Thomas B. Adams departed this morning for Baltimore, New-York and home. I heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Smith from Mark 16:15. “And he said unto them, go ye into all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature.”—upon the universality of the Christian religion. Visit after church from Mr William S. Smith— Attended the Evening service at St. John’s. Mr Hawley read the prayers for Quinquagesima Sunday, and preached from Psalm 25.10. “All the paths of the Lord are Mercy and Truth to such as keep his Covenant and his Testimonies.” The Congregations, both parts of the day were very thin— The ground was covered with Snow, which this day melted off. Choate has lent me the Rules and Orders of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts for this year 1833, which contains a List of the Members of the Legislature and of the Executive Government of the State.

18. V:30. Monday.— At the House— Petitions and Resolutions called for by States— A Resolution to purchase 250 copies of Elliot’s debates on the Constitution, carried by yeas and nays 114 to 65. Sundry small Bills taken up and discussed— Howard presented a petition from the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-road company.— Referred to the Committee which reported a Bill for a loan of 250,000 dollars to pay an instalment of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. I went into the Senate chamber to consult Mr Silsbee, about offering an Amendment to the Bill for refunding duties levied under the 18th. Section of the Tariff Law of the last Session— Silsbee thought it would endanger the Bill— Mr Poindexter was offering an additional Section to the enforcing Bill to make an Appropriation. Debate between Grundy, Calhoun, Poindexter, Smith of Maryland, and finally Forsyth— Soon after he began, I was called back to the House— Tariff-Bill— Motion by Crawford to lay the Bill on the table, offered then withdrawn at the request of Wayne, then renewed, and rejected by yeas and nays 84 to 108. Drayton’s and Wayne’s proposed substitutes are withdrawn— Bouldin has a substitute to propose, but cannot offer it, till all the amendments reported by the Committee of the whole, shall have been decided upon in the House— So the House took up the Amendments where they had been left last week.— The questions upon several of the Amendments were taken by yeas and nays, and carried— Raw Cotton, which the Bill from the Ways and Means had made free of duty had now a protective duty of two Cents a pound restored.— The debate upon crude or fossile Salt was renewed between Jarvis of Maine, and Howard of Maryland, and after an hour or more of discussion the duty was fixed at 1/3 of that upon common Salt. 89—
to 86— The House adjourned soon after 3— My wife was cupped this Evening. Her cough is yet almost incessant.
19. VI. Tuesday.

My wife had another severe fit of coughing for near an hour, between three and four this morning, and several others in the course of this day. Still I cherish a hope that her disease is abating— A Stranger came to solicit a subscription for repairing a Church somewhere in Pennsylvania. I declined; my means having failed. W. S. Smith came with a youth named Constant Freeman, whose mother lives at Baltimore, and he wishes him to be admitted a Cadet at West-Point, as from Massachusetts, because his father once lived there. At the House, the yeas and nays were taken upon a question whether the use of the Hall should be allowed to a Temperance Meeting next Sunday Evening. Tariff-Bill— Motion by Chandler of Maine to reconsider the vote of yesterday laying a duty upon crude or fossile Salt— Sharp debate again between Jarvis, Howard, John Reed, Blair of Tennessee and others— Reconsideration refused 99 to 86. John W. Taylor moved to reconsider the vote of yesterday to lay a duty of 2 Cents a pound on raw cotton— Diverting debate on the question whether this was a protective duty or not. Isaacs, M’Duffie, John Davis, T. H. Hall, Barringer, Vinton, Wilde and others took part in it. Adjourned— Walk home— Talk with John Bell of Tennessee, upon the Tariff, and the enforcing Bill. Mrs W. S. Smith was here this Evening.
20. V. Wednesday

Wrote this morning till I approached the conclusion of my projected report— My wife is still extremely ill; her cough seeming scarcely to abate at all. At the House a Resolution was offered by Henry Horn, that the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to inquire into the expediency of repealing a proviso in the act of 14. July last, which after some discussion was adopted— Tariff-bill resumed Taylor’s motion for reconsidering the duty of two cents a pound upon raw Cotton again debated, and carried— Motions to strike out the two cents, and insert fifteen and twenty per cent ad valorem lost. both taken by yeas and nays. Motion to agree with the Committee of the whole in inserting the two cents lost by yeas and nays 80 to 81. I voted for agreeing with the Amendment of the Committee of the whole and made a few remarks; but my voice failed me greatly— Adjourned at half past four— Met General Wool, just returned from France— Yesterday Mr Chilton Allen introduced to me a young man from Kentucky named Marshall, a nephew of the Chief-Justice. He told me that Mr Clay’s change of opinions would strike his friends in Kentucky like a thunderbolt, and give a great triumph to the Jackson party— Richard Peters was here this Evening—and I had some conversation with him upon the nullification revolt of South-Carolina.
21. V. Thursday.

William Pote came this morning with two Justices of the Peace, before whom I executed the release of the Mortgage which he gave me three years ago, as security for his note for 1000 dollars— Mrs Tudor sent for me yesterday, and again this morning, when I went to her house. She wished me to draw a Petition for her, and to ask Mr Webster to present it to the Senate— Her Petition to the House of Representatives has been unsuccessful. At the House the Bill for enforcing the collection of the Revenue came from the Senate—passed at ten O’Clock last Evening 32 to 1.— All the other members opposed to it having seceded— Long debate in the House whether it should be printed, and order taken to dispose of it. Final refusal to take it up in preference to the Tariff-Bill— That
resumed about 3. P.M. Paragraphs respecting Oils— Amendments of the Committee of the whole rejected, and then adopted, respecting Olive, rape-seed and linseed Oils. Paragraphs laying new duties on Coffee, and Teas, struck out in Committee of the whole. House concur therein by yeas and nays. Motion to adjourn carried by yeas and nays at 6 P.M— Bell of Tennessee asked me if I would vote for a Bill, limiting the Act of 14. July last, to 1. Jany 1835. Conversation with him, and with John Davis— Bell is in no small perplexity.
22. V. Friday.—

Mr Hassler came this morning, to speak of certain mathematical Instruments belonging to the Government of the United States, loaned to the Surveyors for the Geodesical map of the State of Massachusetts now in progress, by an Act of the Legislature of the State. His proposal is that the State should buy the Instruments of the Government of the Union, and they purchase new ones in England. At the House G. C. Washington presented a memorial and remonstrance from a Committee of a meeting of the Inhabitants of the City of Washington, against the Memorial of the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-road company, presented to the House last Monday—referred to the Committee on roads and Canals—a Motion was made by Erastus Root, Chairman of the Committee on Agriculture for purchasing 2000 copies of Cobb’s manual of the Silk worm— Moved to be laid on the Table— Motion rejected by yeas and nays. Michael Hoffman, announced to the House the death last Evening of James Lent junr. a member from the State of New-York—pronounced an Eulogy upon him, and moved the usual Resolutions— The funeral is to be tomorrow at 11. O’Clock A.M.— The House immediately adjourned— I went into the Library, and looked into Gray’s works, for his fragment of verse cited by Gibbon—and then into the Senate where they were engaged upon Mr Clay’s new Tariff-bill— Long debate upon an amendment offered by him. Carried. 26 to 16. Message from the House announcing the death of James Lent junr. Senate adjourned at 4. P.M. Walk home. Hall J. Kelley came to speak of a project in which he is engaged to settle the Oregon Republic, and gave me a copy of its constitution
23. V. Saturday.

My nephews William S. Smith, and John A. Smith were here— The latter, just arrived from New-York— I attended the House at 11. O’Clock. The funeral service over the remains of James Lent junr. was performed by the Chaplain of the House, Mr Hammett— The members as usual followed the deceased to the grave. I rode in the Carriage with Franklin E. Plummer of Mississippi and Henry A. Bullard of Louisiana, both natives of Massachusetts, and a young man from Bullard’s District. The house had adjourned to meet again after the funeral at two O’Clock, and I dined upon a couple of Sandwiches which I had taken in my pocket to be prepared for a day of business But no Quorum could be formed, and after two successive motions to adjourn, a third having been moved without being succeeded by a call for the yeas and nays was carried, about half past two. I went into the Senate chamber, and heard a debate upon Mr Clay’s compromise Bill at the second reading. A debate, brisk, animated, and somewhat acrimonious. About 9. O’Clock in the Evening, the Bill was ordered to be engrossed for a third reading— The votes wereto. Walk home— Mrs Adams is better, but extremely weak—
24. V. Sunday.

Mrs Stewart came this morning to ask me again to draw a petition for her mother, to be presented by Mr Webster to the Senate— But it being too late in the Session, she asked me to return
the papers which I accordingly sent her. I heard this morning at the Presbyterian Church Mr Smith from Romans 8.7 [“]Because the carnal mind is enmity against God; for it is not subject to the Law of God, neither indeed can be.” He gave notice that this was the first of a series of discourses, which he proposes to address to impenitent Sinners— After dinner I heard at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley, read the Evening prayer for the first Sunday in Lent, omitting the Psalms and the first Lesson of the day, and giving instead of a Sermon only a few extemporaneous remarks on Ephesians 5.1. “Be ye therefore followers of God, as dear Children. 2. And walk in love, as Christ also hath loved us, and hath given himself for us, an offering and a sacrifice to God, for a sweet smelling favour.” There were scarcely twenty persons at Church— A great and sudden change of weather from Spring mildness to a Northwest gale, from Lapland, took place just at the hour of afternoon Service— Mr Elisha R. Potter junr was here this Evening— Mrs Adams we hope is convalescent.

25. IV:30. Monday.— At the House, Nathan Appleton, who had leave of absence for the remainder of the Session returned and resumed his Seat. I presented a petition from certain dealers in copper for an alteration of the act of 14. July 1832—by an increase of duty on foreign brazier’s copper. Referred to the Committee of Ways and Means.— Nuckolls of South Carolina presented certain Nullification Resolutions of a Meeting in York district of that State— Vance of Ohio a Memorial from Citizens of that state for aid to the American Colonization Society. Ashley a memorial from the Legislature of Missouri, remonstrating against Mr Clay’s Land-bill— Lewis Condict, Resolutions of the Legislature of New-Jersey against South-Carolina nullification, and approving the President’s Proclamation. Lyon, Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky against South-Carolina Nullification, but not expressing any approbation of the Proclamation— Mardis—Resolutions of the Legislature of Alabama, against South-Carolina Nullification, and against the American System— The Resolution for purchasing 2000 copies of Cobb’s Silk-worm manual was debated till Wickliffe called for the previous question which was sustained, and the Resolution adopted 81. to 75. The enforcing Bill came from the Senate— Its title is an Act further to provide for the collection of duties on imports. Sharp debate on the motion of Bell of Tennessee to make it the order of the day for to-morrow. Thursday and Wednesday proposed— Yeas and Nays several times taken— Tomorrow fixed upon. Tariff-Bill— Letcher moves that it be recommitted to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, with Instructions to report Mr Clay’s Bill, totidem verbis as an amendment— Carried. Wickliffe Chairman of the Committee of the whole; the Bill reported to the House, according to Instructions—report accepted; and the Bill ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow. 105 to 71. Call of the House refused. John Davis and Horace Everett made a very few remarks objecting to the Bill, in vain— It swept like a Hurricane. 30 members absent. All the machinery Representation united. House adjourned after 8 in the Evening— Edward Everett rode home with me.

26. V:30. Tuesday.— I had called the Committee of manufactures to meet at ten this morning. and they met. All the members, were present— I asked them what Report they proposed to make to the House on the subjects referred to them. After debate the majority directed me to ask that the Committee should be discharged from the further consideration of the Subjects referred to them— I then told them that I had prepared a Report for the minority of the Committee which I should present to the House, after requesting for the Committee to be discharged. Hoffman said he should oppose the reception of this Report by the House— He made attempts to get possession of it, and asked for the reading of it— I read about four pages of it when the Committee
adjourned till tomorrow morning at 9. In the House, the Clay Tariff-Bill was passed by Previous Question 119 to 85. I desired to ask a question with regard to the construction of the first Section of the Bill, but was not permitted. The Revenue Collection Bill, otherwise called the Force Bill, or as the nullifiers call it the Bloody Bill was then taken up and a very disorderly struggle to put it off continued till four O’Clock, when the House took a recess till six. I came home, dined and returned at six. The whole evening was spent upon business of the District of Columbia, and several Bills were passed through the Committee of the whole. John W. Taylor in the Chair till past ten, when the Committee rose for want of a Quorum and the House adjourned. It was about 11. when I got home, and immediately retired to bed. I prevailed by intreaty upon the House to devote this Evening to the District. John Davis had moved to strike it out of the Resolution.

27. VI. Wednesday.— The Committee of Manufactures met again this morning at 9. The reading of my Report was not resumed, but Hoffman complained that the Report took the Majority by surprise, and announced in a very menacing tone, that he should oppose its being received; that he would insist upon its being read through, and would then speak against it to the last moment of the Session to prevent its being printed by order of the House. He said he was going out of public Life, and wished to part in Peace and Friendship with everyone. He hoped therefore that I would agree to some arrangement of this matter. I asked him what arrangement he proposed. He said it was that I should not present the Report to the house. To this I answered that terrific as his threats were, I could not agree to his arrangement.— There was sharp discussion, till the adjournment of the Committee without day— At the meeting of the House, I requested in the name of the Majority of the Committee of Manufactures, that they should be discharged from further consideration of the Subjects referred to them, and then offered the Report of the Minority of the Committee, signed by Dr Condict and myself which I moved should be laid on the table and printed— Hoffman then objected, and called for the reading of the Report— Ten pages of it were read, until at Noon, the House passed to the orders of the day. The District bills were then passed. Then the revenue Collection or force Bill was taken up. Carson spoke against it. At 4. the House took a recess till six. I came home, dined and returned at 6. Clayton of Georgia spoke against the Bill— Isacks of Tennessee, Blair of South-Carolina, and Wayne of Georgia in favour of it. M’Duffie about ten O’Clock at Night moved an adjournment, which succeeded.

28. VI. Thursday. At the House, the Committee of Ways and Means made two Reports— That of the majority, favourable to the Bank of the United States; and that of the Minority by Polk against it. The Report of the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures was taken up. I moved that the further reading of it be dispensed with—that it be laid on the table and printed— Hoffman moved that it should not be received, but the Speaker told him it was too late for that— It had been received, and partly read, and was before the House. Hoffman then asked for a division of the question upon my motion to be taken first on laying on the table, and then on the printing— The laying on the table was agreed to without a division, and Hoffman commenced a Speech against the printing which continued till twelve O’Clock, and was unfinished when the House passed to the order of the day. M’Duffie then made his Speech against the enforcing Bill, or rather in vindication of the nullification Ordinance of South-Carolina—for in a Speech of three hours he just made out to reach the Bill before the House, and then sat down— The House then took a recess from 3 to 5 O’Clock. At the urgent invitation of Thomas Newton, the member from Norfolk
Virginia, I went and dined with him at his lodgings— Thomas Marshall of Kentucky, and John J. Milligan of Delaware, both members of the House are fellow lodgers, and boarders with him; and John Taliaferro, formerly a member from Virginia, also lodges there. He was there when we arrived, but was engaged to dine abroad, and soon went away. We had a short and cheerful dinner, and at 5. returned to the House— I had offered in the morning a joint Resolution, to suspend for the present Session of Congress, the 17th. and 18th. joint Rules for the transaction of business— The 17th. being that no bill, originating in either house should be sent to the other, on the last three days of the Session— The 18th. is that no Bill shall be sent to the President for his approbation, on the last day of the Session.— There was a Resolution from the Senate to suspend so far the 17th Rule, that the Houses should receive original Bills from each other, to-morrow and Saturday. I now moved to amend the Resolution from the Senate, by striking out the whole of it, after the word Resolved, and inserting my Resolution in it stead. This after much captious debate was adopted by a large majority, and was concurred in by the Senate— Isacks of Tennessee told me that the President had religious scruples against signing Bills on a Sunday. I shewed him in the Statute Book, eight or ten Laws, approved by Mr Jefferson, Sunday 3. March 1805— The Revenue Collection-bill was taken up— Wayne of Georgia spoke in support of the Bill— Foster of Georgia, and Daniel of Kentucky against it— All long Speeches— Craig of Virginia moved the Previous Question, which after much chicanery was carried 110 to 44— The vote to engross the Bill for a 3d. reading was 126 to 34— Bell moved the third reading now. Warren R. Davis, Gordon, Coulter, Coke and Bouldin, all wanted to speak against the Bill, and Wickliffe got up one of his questions of order; on pretence that the Bill had not been read; and that is was one, which by the rule of the House must go through a Committee of the whole.— The Bill was read; and the Speaker decided that it needed not go through a Committee of the whole— Beardsley moved the previous Question, that the Bill be read a third time now, and it was carried 111 to 40. The House then adjourned about half past one O’Clock in the Morning without taking the Question upon the Bill. The Speaker this morning called me to the Chair of the Committee of the whole, on three private Bills— Just before midnight while Daniel was speaking, Branch offered to pair off with me but I declined
Day— Absorbed in public business.
